There isn't much to dislike about Canon's SL3 SLR camera.  I buy camera bodies often, keep them a year and then often upgrade (I travel for a living).I have yet to find a really good POINT & SHOOT camera to carry for my travels.  They always let me down (Canon included) in performance.Now comes another SL series Canon camera (I thought the Sl1 and SL2 were dismal and cheap) called the SL3.  Still offered in the tacky 'White' version as well as the classic black body.I'm not about to list all of the specs (you can read those on your own by visiting the Canon website) here but I will keep this basic and to the point.  I've purchased two of these (one on the day it was released and another from Amazon).Let's go right to the processor (DIGIC 8)...  This is a rocket ship processor in speed and lighting.  Dark closets, no flash, no tripod, etc, etc, etc all still produced vivid photos when I tested the SL3 I had just purchased.  In fairness, I did use a SanDisk Extreme Pro 300MG card for speed but that card had nothing to do with lighting.  I also used a L-Series IS lens which was e real reason for the superior lighting conditions produced.The camera body is made in Taiwan.  Mostly plastic and very lightweight.  The GRIP of the body is fabulous.  The so-called KIT lens (18-55mm) is sub-par in performance but it's an excellent lightweight inexpensive lens if weight is an issue.  The SL3 will accept both EF-S lenses and EF lenses.Because I travel and carry way too much equipment, I wanted Canon to produce a fantastic Point & Shoot.  They did not.  Along comes the SL3  (red flags already after the Sl1 and SL2).  Was I ever wrong...I was so glad I tried the SL3.  Lightweight.  Even with the basic lens kit (F4 18-55mm lens) made mostly of plastic, it still did a great job of beating out any Point & Shoot.  Plus at only 2 lbs for body and lens with battery.  It was a BMW in performance despite being inexpensive, made of all plastic and a bit flimsy at times for switches and controls.This is no Canon 6D Mark II or 5D IV.  Not even close.  But keep the cost in mind.  Keep the weight in mind.  Mostly, keep that fabulous Digic 8 processor in mind.  So impressive.A great choice.  Actually, a bit under-priced I think.Canon hit a home run in the SL3.

The body alone is worth the sell-price of this package, and the accessories are just a bonus. It's been a long while now since I bought my Digital Rebel XTi, way back at the beginning of 2007, and I am thoroughly satisfied with this upgrade to the 2017 SL2 model. I vacillated between the SL2 and the T6i, but finally concluded that the SL2 advantages, slight though they were, are better suited to the kind of photography I most enjoy (which is nature, animals, still-life and macro). The SL2 represents a major, major update over my old XTi -- as you'd expect after 10 years.Overall, this is another excellent camera, from a thoroughbred line and I am very pleased. I recommend getting an additional memory card and the OAproda LP-E17 battery 2-Pack with USB charger (https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B071SFNX2F/) to go with it. There is a noticeable improvement in the photos taken, even with the same lens, when compared to my older camera.Highlights: The focusing system is excellent, and very fast. Live view is wonderful for framing in awkward shooting positions (e.g. close to the ground) and for tripod work with remote release. The higher pixel density provides much better options for cropping while still being able to produce large prints from the resulting images (especially if the print service uses optical enlargement instead of digital). The colors and exposure automatic setting work much better than my old camera (though I always post-process in DP4). Low-light seems vastly improved, with less noise at the same ISO, but I have yet to use it in a really demanding situation. The feature set is really, really good. I love the triple-shot automatic HDR mode -- it works really well. The menu and settings are very well done and easy to use. Button placement is well thought out and also easy to use.Complaints: None, so far.Accessories: These range from necessary to useful to complete crap. Necessary are strap, charger, battery, memory card (fast and large), card-reader, remote shutter release (a really useful add-on). Useful are the camera bag, flash, flash-extension arm, video handstrap, lens adapters (surprisingly good as a *starter* for macro and telephoto work), and lens filters (UV, C-Polariser and Florescent). Crap are the tripod (don't breathe, it'll shake) and flash shades. The accessories were mainly useful to me in combining with my old body and one lens, to a kit for my kids. The accessories do provide a good starting base and I would have been happy to get them if I was starting out.The flash is nowhere near as good as my Canon SpeedLite but better and more versatile than the built-in. The flash arm was a nice touch.The lens adapters are surprisingly higher quality than I expected, and my kids are putting them to good use -- which suits me fine as I really don't like them using my high-end macro/portrait lens.The camera bag is good as a starter, but on the small size. Really just room for the camera, principle lens, one extra lens and some accessories. My equipment wouldn't fit, and the kids outfit fills it up. Still, not bad at all.Caveat: There is one interesting caveat with this offering. As an upgrade kit for most buyers half of the accessories are redundant and worthless. But for a first-time buyer, the lack of a lens is a huge oversight. So the perfect buyer is someone with an existing Canon EOS camera looking to pass along the old camera body with the kit len(es) that came with the original purchase (as I was).

review_title: Don’t listen to naysayers, this is an amazing camera.
review_body: This camera is a joy to use and takes amazing pictures. The evaluative metering works ridiculously well, even pulling off metering of backlit subjects with very little compensation needed. The auto white balance basically can’t be fooled and is the best I’ve ever seen. The touch screen with flippy ability is a pleasure to use. The remote app for your phone actually works unlike some other brands, and you can control your camera with your phone.Reviewers biggest complaint is about dynamic range. Yes it’s true that it’s range is not as big as some, however, if you’re not trying to lift the shadows of an underexposed by two stops image, you’ll never notice. As it is, the pictures this thing takes when correctly exposed are marvelous. It’s fantastic in low light too, with usable images at even 12800 iso.The 6d2 is also a very comfortable camera to hold. It’s ergonomics are top notch. I do wish the outer material was the same as the 5d series, but it’s a comfortable grip nonetheless. The controls are well placed, and once set up you rarely have to dive into a menu.If you plan to record video or do any vlogging, the face tracking rarely falters. It’s pretty remarkable. You can confidently record yourself without worrying about focus, even while walking around town.Overall, the camera is a joy to use, and anyone complaining about it, hasn’t used one, or is just letting numbers cloud their judgment.

For this model, Nikon finally enabled the LiveView to be high enough to see through 10-stop ND filters, or to be able to focus at night, as its ISO 1M gives you a bright enough image. If run in video LiveView, you can now also have two sets of parameters, one for high ISO focusing, the other for shooting, something not even the D6xx series can do (only starting with the D750 and higher).Together with the tilting screen, latest processor and familiar feel, this is a highly recommended upgrade to any D3xxx, D5xxx or D7xxx owner.

review_title: Camera is terrific, Accessory package useful and not all junk
review_body:
This review is for the product right out of the box as it arrived today. It would be at least a month before I could use everything enough to comment on things like quality and durability. So this is my initial impression.When unpacking the items it appeared that some of the boxes had previously been opened so I was a bit wary. However, upon opening the boxes, everything was in its original packaging and nothing appeared to be used or damaged.Canon D6 mkii - There are reviews for this all over the place. I won't go into depth other than to say it works as expected. I've tested it by taking several photos and a video. I used it with and without the battery grip and with and without the flash. It came with a strap, Canon battery and charger in the box.Canon battery grip BG-E21 - I haven't had time to figure out what all the buttons are for, but I did load a couple of batteries into it and attach it to the camera. It is easy to install and works like a charm.Bower Flash SFD740C - This appears solid and rather well made. It is heavier than I expected it to be. It has a built in retractable reflector and diffuser which seems rather convenient and an adjustable power level. It does seem a bit slow to recharge compared to my Canon Speed lite, but it is certainly serviceable. It's a keeper and will go into my camera bag. UPDATE 12/01: When using the wifi app to connect the camera to my phone for use as a remote trigger, this flash will not flash. I thought it might be something with the app, but my Canon 420ex works perfectly so it is definitely a problem with this flash.Vivitar batteries - There were three of these. So far I have charged two with the third one charging as I write this. I can't comment on how long they will last or the quality other than to say they work.Vivitar universal wireless shutter release - UPDATE 12/01: This is worthless and doesn't work.SanDisk Extreme SDXC UHS-1 memory card - It came with 2 of these. Both work and should be capable of storing lots of photos and capturing full HD video. They are SanDisk which is about as good as it gets.Vidpro microphone XM-40 - I haven't used this yet so no comment on it. I already own a Rode so this will likely end up a backup.XIT Photo hard case - No way do I put expensive gear in this thing. It feels like it would fall apart if I dropped it. But I'll use it to store a few accessories that I rarely use or take with me.Ultimax 57" tripod and Deck Gear 72" monopod - Cheap and lightweight. I will trust neither to hold my expensive gear. I bought small cameras for my granddaughters for Christmas. These should make good presents to go with them.DM 12 inch tripod - Not exactly sturdy, but easily the better tripod. It will work well on my desk with my Logitech C922 webcam. This one I keep.There is a set of 3 flash diffusers, but I have no idea how to attach them to the flash.Miscellaneous cleaning supplies - Should come in handy.Overall, this package was the same price as the camera by itself so its hard to complain about it. Instead I will say I am pleasantly surprised at the quality of some of the items and will disregard the rest.

review_title: Simple, stunning, and well thought out, but not as versatile as a standard 35mm DSLR/mirrorless.

I have to agree that this is not really a carry around camera.  Its ISO performance is not as good as my D810 or A7rii, but that was known before I purchased it.  I agree with most reviewers that this should be used with controlled lighting situations where motion is little to none.Since I shoot mostly portrait photography, the detail I have found with this camera is incredible.  I really like how simple the camera is setup.  The auto focus is great. Controls are easily accessible, customization is very easy, menu systems are straightforward.  Unlike with the A7rii, I don't have to go searching for what I want to change.So is it worth the price?  If you are planning on using this like you would a 35mm, then I would say no.  You can get a lot more use range with a 35mm (DSLR/mirrorless) than you would with this camera.  But if you are into taking shots under controlled conditions for very high resolution and spectacular range, then yes.  It's just a matter of how bad you want those fine details for those specific shots.  This darn camera makes me look like I actually know what I am doing.

review_title: Superb in low light and shadow definition. Great color science
review_body: For my style of work, this is an excellent camera. I tend to shoot dimly lit, high contrast subject matter, it excels under these circumstances.Recent cameras I have owned: gh4, 2 a7s2's, a7r2, a6500, a6300The gh5s is far superior to the a7s2, hands down, maybe 20X better color retention in the shadows. Far greater detail in the shadows and almost no pixelation. Panasonic 4k 60fps 8bit footage is far superior to sony a7s2 4k 30fps 10bit recorded externally with an atomos ninja flame. In fact most projects shot on the panasonic never even require 10bit recording because the color science is spot on, and the footage is very pliable in 8bit.Autofocus is significantly better than past panasonic cameras. Not as good as sony. I shoot a large variety of subjects, one of them are MMA fighters, UFC embedded style, which doesn't allow for retakes. This is NOT the best camera for those types of shoots. However if you have enough talent and skills it could be done. The camera does not focus hunt the way past panasonics did, it may go out of focus once in a while, but it will eventually find focus smoothly. The GH4 would constantly switch focus plains over and over which makes footage unusable. I find that the GH5s actually focuses better in dark situations, and struggles in evenly lit situations.If you are looking to take photos I would look elsewhere. Most phones probably work better.When compared to other cameras in this range, this is hands down one of the best out there. It is 100% a film making tool, NOT A YOUTUBER camera. With proper preparation and execution you could almost film a feature film with a set of these. It is on par with lower end RED cameras like the raven, with the exception of frame rates.

To give some background I currently own the Gh4 and the Gh5 - and I use them to film all sorts of stuff - I mainly shoot weddings, and these little cameras are superb at doing just that.  Before buying this I already knew about the lack of IBIS so that wasn't a deal breaker for me like others - and I still own the Gh5.  However the Gh5s is such an amazing addition to my Panasonic Fleet! Anyone that owns any MFT camera knows and deals with the fact that low light filming is practically non-existent - unless of course you bring some LED lighting.  With the introduction of a slightly wider sensor and enhanced magic - this Gh5s is superb in low light.  The build feels identical to the Gh5 and the field of view looks slightly larger when teamed up with my Metabones and 18-35 Sigma Art 1.8For those of you that already own the gh5 this is NO replacement - this camera is just another tool in your arsenal.  Although this is a great camera to replace the Gh4 if that's something you already own.  I also like the inclusion of VLOG already installed into this camera - it allows me to play with this video setting before trying to purchase it for my Gh5.Note:- The color science between the Gh5 and Gh5s are slightly different, I suspect that it has to do with the sensor size - in my honest opinion, the Gh5s shows a warmer color science compared to the Gh5- Gh4 and Gh5 batteries and accessories work with Gh5s- Batteries last almost a whole on a single charge compared to the Gh5So far, I haven't had any issues arise from this camera - I'll update this review if it's necessary!

Wanted to post a review, since there aren't many reviews of the GH5s. Before I bought this camera, I owned the Panasonic G7, but I have used some cinema cameras as well, so I'll try to compare it to those too.PROS:-Excellent dynamic range (12 or 12.5 very usable stops in V-log), particularly in the shadows. Just remember not to underexpose.-Incredible resolution and sharpness in video, especially in 4k.-Despite small and compressed file sizes, its amazing how much you can push the color in post. File sizes are about 9 times smaller than Blackmagic Prores files I've edited.-Great 4K slow motion in "Natural" profile. If you want to shoot in V-log, I'd actually use the 10-bit 1080p 60 fps. Some color issues in 8-bit 4k when grading skin-tones in V-log and 1080p is still sharp.-Lots of things make this similar to a low-end cinema camera. You can get zebras, waveforms, shoot in V-log etc. Lots of room to ensure consistency and I think the image quality is among the best I've seen.-Usability. DSLR ergonomics, great battery life (especially with battery grip), weather sealing etc. I can take this camera everywhere and it's been very sturdy and reliable. Image quality looks great through 6400 iso and very usable through 12,800 iso.CONS:-Variable frame rate over 60 fps is really not good for most situations. Lots of horizontal noise/banding unless you shoot in "Natural" profile at 200 iso or less. Above 96fps, some really bad moire and aliasing too. Fun to have the slow motion, but not the most professional footage.-A little bit large for my Zhiyun Crane v2 gimbal. No shake, just hard to go into inverted mode without closing and reopening the touchscreen.-Ergonomics. Great to take everywhere you go, but you'll miss variable ND filters and built-in XLR ports for audio compared to a number of cinema cameras.-Photos aren't that sharp due to ~10MP sensor. No surprise there.

Ok, I wanted to give this camera a few weeks before I gave it a review. I love it. I'm coming from using Canon cinema cameras (still own a couple) and wanted something in a smaller form factor. Lugging C100 gear everywhere can be cumbersome (beautiful images but cumbersome) so I gave the GH5S a shot. I'm not a huge fan of the original GH5's color science. The skin tones come off very orange (to my eye) but the GH5S has a more natural look. After adding a MB .71 adapter and a Canon 24-105 (which becomes a 30-135 2.8 with I.S.), I'm completely happy. The color science of this camera is beautiful and having 4K 60p or 1080p 4:2:2 in camera is just brilliant. It already comes with V-Log installed which is another bonus. Honestly? I still feel like I have a lot to learn with this camera but so far, I'm really happy with it and it's giving me beautiful images. If I want a stabilizer, I'll use a Ronin or Zhiyun Crane, Monopod or stabilized lens. The color science and low light capabilities are more important to me and it's like using other cinema cameras. Panasonic delivered. 2 thumbs up.

review_title: This one is for you,  no matter your level!!
review_body: I purchased this camera to launch a YouTube Channel “Refreshingly CozChristopher” and for my children “A CoZ Life.” For a first time Mirrorless owner, there is a learning curve as there is no “beginners” mode! I believe that to be the beauty and strength of this camera, you can control the settings via touchscreen or manually via the ISO, Shutter Speed, Exposure, etc. dials!! You have the ability to really learn the manual interface of this camera and learn true photography/videography!I decided on the XT3 over the Black Cinema Pocket Camera, the A7iii and the EOS R for its superb video capabilities 4K 60 10-bit at 400mbs internal to start and it’s 26.2 strong photo presence. Allowing me to start with a robust multi-use camera from the beginning at a fraction of the cost of the others. The only camera with better video capabilities currently is the BMCC but it has no photo capabilities! This camera is a real “Cinema” camera for the cost of an entry/mid level DSLR or Mirrorless. I’m retrospect it’s priced like an 80D or A6400 but performs like an A7iii or EOS R or S1!As far as the bundle that came with it. For a seasoned professional they would replace every piece with established quality gear, for someone starting from scratch it was priceless bonus that allowed me to invest in other much needed equipment! And a 128gb card for free!!?? This price for just the camera and arguably the best “kit” lens and I mean major “ “ because with OIS in the lens 18-55 and auto or manual aperture, this package is a no brainer for a seasoned professional looking to jump into the Fuji Lineup, someone looking to start from scratch, someone in the middle that wants to take advantage of the amazing cost to value benefit or just anyone who takes photography/videography serious or plans to in the future! This is for you!

I upgraded from a Canon 70D and couldn't be more satisfied.  After years of going "cheap" with APC cameras, going full frame for this price was a no-brainer. I have big hands but find the RP's handling excellent -- button/wheel location is excellent for my needs (mostly amateur travel, portraiture, some sports).  The optional grip works well for a heavier lens, but you can certainly go without.  The build is nice and solid, although the LCD screen if extended seems a tad fragile.  The EVF is sharp and bright.  AF is good if not lightning fast.  You can find several complaints online about the RP (old 6D2 sensor, low FPS, short battery life), but hey, at this price and coming from a 70D, I am very pleased. The RF lens is very sharp and a perfect all-around.  Having the new control ring on the lens is great (I actually programmed it to set ISO). review_title: EOS RP From an Old Canon 6D User
review_body: I own both the original 6D as well as the RP. Ive only had the RP for a short time, but here are some of my impressions. All in all, it seems to be a very good camera. Other than the resolution, I still prefer the images from my 6D but as I said, its early yet.I think the body is a little cheapy feeling. The ergonomics are good and you really dont need the extra bottom plate unless you have gigantic hands. It has a good grip and as everyone has mentioned, its very light. Of course until you add some big EF lenses. Other than the nice grip it tends to remind me of a Sony in that everything is minimal, controls are flush to the body, all black. I would have prefered a little better leatherette cover, and some more slr like controls. However, im being picky here and this would all affect the size and weight of the camera.The EVF is a top notch feature.  For landscapes in particular, there really has been no other way but Live View through the LCD, but that has changed. You can almost forget about the rear LCD except for certain purposes, the EVF is that good. It allows you to control everything and see everything including exposure. You can see in the EVF whether the sky is blown out etc. And thanks to drag and focus, you can easily move the focus point , get the exposure you like and lock it in with exposure lock. It is very much like having a peephole LCD. Big points for this.The autofocus is excellent and you can have a combination of them in place at the same time. The eye detect focus from my limited use is very fast and does a great job. If you want to to change the focus, just touch your LCD while looking through the EVF and you can move it, almost anywhere in the frame.There are a number of other great features such as focus bracketing that ive yet to try, but that one has the potential to be great. So all that being said, lets get to the image quality.Anyone moving from an aps-c to full frame Im sure will be very impressed with the RP. With a good lens you cant beat that combination of razor sharp and creamy soft that full frame offers. The colors of course are very good as expected, and here is a surprize. I was expecting the DR to be a real downer but its not. I convert to dng and edit in other programs other than DPP and i was surprised at how much range there is. Its certainly not class leading, but it is very respectable. If you need more than this, you really took a bad exposure. The low light performance is very good, and you can get very respectable images even beyond 12800 ISO with a little work. Now i have to say this, for whatever reason, i still prefer the images of the original 6D. I cant say exactly why, a combination of the tone, color and what i like to call the creaminess is still better for me on the 6D. But again I am splitting hairs. For the most part, the RP is capable of producing images rivaling the best of Canons full frame cameras. And it has a lot of practical convenience features that make this one hell of a camera for the price.

The manual clearly states that "processing RAW images from this camera is not possible". I wish I had known this, I would not have bought this camera. While the camera does allow you to shoot in RAW, you cannot download or open the files on your computer. You have to go to the Canon website and download software. The instructions to do so are confusing, and the instructions on how to actually use the software are even more confusing.Unless you plan on only shooting in JPEG, do not buy this camera.The autofocus and shutter (there is a lag or delay when you press the shutter) are so slow on this camera, don't even think about trying to capture moving subjects. I tried to shoot my dog jumping in broad daylight, and it was impossible. Nothing but complete blur. Also, because it is completely digital, the viewfinder and image display shut off after you take a shot, as it is processing. The viewfinder itself is also digital as well...which totally negates the purpose of having a viewfinder...

review_title: Replaced two cameras for this professional instagrammer
review_body: I say “professional instagrammer” in the title as a half joke. I’m a hairdresser who makes much of my living through hair-related social media, just to give you an idea of what I use this camera for as you read on.If you know what you’re buying this is a five star purchase. If you think this camera will compete with a Sony for video or a DSLR for action, then you’re going to be disappointed. This is a “pictures of people” camera that has some very light video features. It’s not a cinema camera, it’s not an action camera. For what it does it is phenomenal— it’s a tiny, lightweight, and FUN camera with intuitive controls that will easily make use of any of that old EF or EF-S glass you’ve had laying around.People complain of the adapter adding length but physics require this, as any pro level mirrorless lenses are longer than similar DSLR lenses. In fact the RF 50mm F1.2L is the same overall size as the EF 85mm F1.2L mounted on the adapter (see photo).I highly recommend upgrading to the control ring adapter, which can be programmed to perform several functions (mine controls aperture in manual mode and exposure compensation in aperture priority mode). In fact one of the last things I saw on this camera that made me decide to buy it was the fact that you can customize the function of just about every button and dial, which makes it YOUR camera and helps to learn all of the features easily (I disabled many things off the bat to make the camera function more efficiently for me)Before I owned this camera I was using a Canon 5D mark iii for studio portraits and a Canon SL2 for vlog type videos. This camera has replaced both of those others, and with a smaller footprint than either. However, I am not an action, event, or low light photographer and my video work is very simple and breezy.I usually like to make big camera purchases from my local brick and mortar, however they didn’t offer the EOS RP without a kit lens, so I bought this package on amazon. I chose this package for the two memory cards, which I needed anyways, but all the rest of the stuff went straight to a donation bin, so I can’t comment on any of its quality.

I wasn't going to buy this camera since I already have a Canon 5DIV but then I wanted a smaller camera for traveling. After going through everything available from point and shoot to small MLC's, I pulled the trigger on the RP. It takes some adjusting from an optical viewfinder but it's not a big deal. Advantages over my DSLR include better focus and WYSIWYG in the electronic viewfinder. The IQ is very good, essentially the same as the 6DMK2. Adapting EF and EF-s glass works without any problems but the lens does protrude pretty far out. The only things I don't like are the auto silent mode, which IMO silent shutter should just be an option and work in manual also. Also the battery is small and there is no power grip available although I have to admit I am getting over 300 pics on a charge as long as I don't do picture previews or use the LCD screen a lot. Overall it is a well thought out camera and the bundle including the EF adapter and extension grip is a good deal.

review_title: A powerful and lightweight camera at a nice price
review_body: I am a professional photographer who wanted a smaller camera, preferably mirrorless. I also didn’t want to spend an arm and a leg on one of the really high-end Canon models. The RP has been a great choice for me, and after two road trips using the RP I know I have a winner.Size-wise, it’s perfect. In fact, even though I have small hands I found that the grip mount (included in this bundle) is necessary to get a good grip on the camera. The Canon Mount Adapter works as advertised with my existing EF and EF-S lenses; note that the camera does not provide full-frame capabilities with those older lenses, only the new RF lenses.The capabilities of the RP are incredible; just reading the manual can take a while! I think the best way to really learn all of the different modes and settings is to go through each section of the manual and then deliberately set up a photo shoot to try them.Both the EVF and back display are crisp, clear and readable. I appreciated the adjustment on the EVF for my glasses, and the information provided in the EVF is precisely what you’ll need - you can customize it as well. The proof of the pudding, so to speak, is the imaging quality of the camera and I’ve found it to be very good. Colors are bright and saturated, but not overly so. Contrast is excellent, and the resolution of the sensor is good enough to allow sharp printouts in big sizes without pixelation.One negative with both the RP and EOS R is that the .CR3 RAW format is not currently supported by most software. Until it is, you can still shoot RAW + JPEG and work with the JPEG images...waiting for the RAW support in the future.I love the quietness of the EOS RP and the almost total lack of vibration when taking photos. After using this excellent mirrorless camera, I know I will never get a regular DSLR again.

review_title: Great first full-frame upgrade for Canon users
review_body: I purchased this camera to supplant my 12-year-old EOS 30D.  I had been considering the 6D MkII as well and I liked one when I tried it out a while back, but I ended up going with the EOS RP because it would be easier to travel with and would give me a wider range of lens compatibility in the future since it includes an EF adapter.I specifically wanted to upgrade to full-frame and I already have several Canon lenses so I was only considering a Canon camera, so you may want to do your own research about the wider camera market before making a decision if this is your first interchangeable-lens camera.On to the pros and cons of the camera in my time of ownership:Pros:1) Full-frame sensor which means better low light performance and no annoying 1.6x crop factor on EF lenses2) Much smaller and lighter than any other full-frame camera by Canon, and most other brands too from what I gather3) Cheaper than the 6D Mk II even though it has the same image sensor and newer processor4) Able to accept EF and RF lenses; included EF adapter works flawlessly, even accepts EF-S lenses (but only at 10 megapixels)5) For still photography, not much reason to get the much more expensive EOS R6) Canon ergonomics are amazing as always7) MODE WHEEL INSTEAD OF THE STUPID EOS R TOUCHBARCons:1) Worse battery life than a DSLR because the image sensor is always active, plus it uses the battery from the Rebel series, no battery grip available like there is for the EOS-R either2) Much fewer video options than EOS R if you care about that3) RF lens ecosystem is not filled out yet so you'll be using the included adapter a lot for the next couple years unless you're made of money4) No room for a top screenOther points that may help:1) Uses an electronic viewfinder instead of optical.  This has positive and negative effects so I would try out a camera with each to see what you like better2) Less weather sealing than the EOS R3) Includes the most basic RF to EF lens adapter but fancier ones are available if you want--Now, onto this specific package deal.  I have purchased from DigitalGoja before which is why I bought from them this time.  As always the item was securely packaged and I have no complaints there.  Here are the pros and cons of this package:Pros:1) Included accessories are high quality.  MagicFiber cloths are actually my favorite microfiber cloths and one is included, camera case and monopod are good quality for freebies even though they're not name brand.2) Includes 2 memory cards3) Canon authorized sellerCons:1) SD cards are not great for 4K video if that is what you're going to do with this camera (although I wouldn't recommend this camera for that anyway)2) Only includes one battery (but spares are cheap)3) Does not include the grip extender (won't matter unless you have big hands; it isn't a battery grip anyway)--TL;DR: Great "entry" full-frame upgrade for Canon users.  Same image characteristics as other Canon cameras.  Can use EF lenses and the new RF lenses, which are all very good so far but not many entry level options exist yet.  Great for still photography but not amazing for video.  Included freebies are good and DigitalGoja is an authorized Canon dealer.Attached image is straight out of the camera with an EF 85mm f/1.8 lens using the included adapter.
review_body

I own a small advertising firm. 8 artist 3 office staff 6 assistants, annually in the millions so i feel qualified to review this.Basically this is a 5d iv with a swivel screen and evf, but for under 2g's with some extras. So keeping that in mind, the most important to me is 1. End product the customer is happy with 2. My bottom line.Out of the camera stills are not as sharp as a sony a9, but again compare the price, after some work in lightroom using Canon's dual pixel raw the end product is better. That's right! If you are good with lightroom you will find the canon cr3 raw files do considerably better, especially drawing back the shadows much less noise introduced.I don't worry much about video on this, i have cinema line cameras for that, but the hub-bub about cropping at 4k is silly, don't think "crop" think what lense do i need since i know my equiptment. After 30 years, i can look at my scene as a blank canvas, invision what i want to see, make it happen by knowing my equiptment, selecting the right lenses and setting.  If you can't do that, then you'll be a youtuber giving biased reviews based on who gives you what. Please don't listen to them. If this camera does not give you good results it might be you, not the camera!You can use ef-s lenses! Great i have some of those and there good, and inexpensive! So if your my business, scrapping to make a living doing ads from auto manufacturing and corporate fast food mostly things get banged up, cheap is good if the final is good.Very, very rugged. If i didn't break this in a week you won't. It has taken some mud, rain and a 5 foot drop no prob.Oh, you probably spend money on accessories, you can save here too. Same battery as a 5d, 6d, 80d ect. So say you want to upgrade from a 80d you already have the extra batteries!Sigma and tamron lenses i have tested on this, no prob! Dont know why, i put a 2x extender on my 50-500 sigma, still had auto focus. Lens is a 6.3 @500 so you do the math.Feels good to hold, for me nicer than my 1dx, never liked how a nikon or fuji felt. Sony is on par, but it's preference.To be fair, i only use this for candids and set photo ops, sometimes auto exects travel to give input on ads, they may be visiting from japan or germany to detroit so i send them away with some free 8x10s or whatever. That's the limits for me with this type of camera, so keep in mind my opinions are that, i don't do weddings or cheerleading squads or that type of thing.Are worried about 2 cards?  Do what i did monday, download the canon connect app, connect your camera to tablet set it to auto load, end of the day all your raws are on the card and on your tablet, use dropbox have your office push them to your in house cloud. Have your assistant process and print, while they do that take your client to lunch, when you get back to your office they will be surprised to see beautiful prints waiting on the confrence room table! And you have 3 raw copies and didnt carry around 100+ dollar sd cards in your pocket! Problem solved man.Your probably concerned that little swipe bar button thing is a joke? It's not, in fact its my new favorite thing, hold for 5 secs to activate. I have ot set so-swipe iso up down, or bump left for auto iso or bump right for 100 iso. After 5 secs it deactivates and doesnt "move by mistake screwing up shots" as one blogger thats biased reported. He and his wife are just upset they can't get their cameras to work like mine, and not worried what car they should buy to complement thier 458 like i am. Can't afford the hybrid, I'm just a photographer ya know.Bottom line, i bought this to try it, waited a while to make sure there were no big issues. I'm a local small business and support such, lucky for me my brick camera store sells on amazon, today i went to such store to talk shop and place an order for 3 more, getting the control ring adaptor this time! Nice featureSo, you can get a camera with a 5d sensor, adaptor and backpack (i just toss it on a closet but at least its there) a decemt strap, micro cloth and some other junk for 2grand. And your reading this? Just buy the thing will you, and learn who to listen to, how to use lightroom photoshop premier pro dimensions and you'll be fine.Oh yeah, while not ibis, there is a digital stabilizer in video modes. I used enhanced and it worked. Yes, stabilization in lense is much better, not getting into that though but it is. Now stop worring about what camera to buy and whatching gear youtubers and go use one!

review_title: A big jump from the EOS 7D!
review_body: This camera is really a fantastic tool. Bigger sensor than my APS-C in the 7D, RAW images are sometimes 65MB+ so lots more data in them. Gorgeous images. Too many features on the camera to list but the biggest surprise is the value of the touchscreen for so many of the  settings and even taking an image by tapping the screen. review_title: The Camera Is Pretty Damned Fragile
review_body: I bought my first NikonP900 earlier this year. A few months later I fell on some steps in Florence italy, while the camera was around my neck but turned off and with all moveable parts closed. There is slight cosmetic damage, but the zoom seems to works normally. "Seems," because the other electronics are shot. The shutter doesn't respond and both the LCD screen and the viewfinder stay dark & useless.When I took the P900 to an excellent camera repair shop which I've used before (for Canon cameras and lenses), I learned that the P900 "cannot be repaired." It turns out that means it can only be repaired by Nikon.The P900 was recommend to me by a friend who is a professional photographer, and I accept I was probably at fault. I banged my knees up pretty badly, too. So I did not contact Amazon or the Amazon seller or Nikon. But I like the camera. I  ordered a 2nd P900 on June 21st from an Amazon seller named "Pixiebytes"--perhaps that cutesy name should have been a warning. It arrived June 25. Since I already knew the model, I did not use it much before a second trip to Italy, July 21-August 5. For about a week the new camera seemed to be working fine, but then one day I turned it on and the LCD screen remained dark. It is still dark and useless. The view finder works and one can even review photos on the SD card, albeit it poorly and with difficulty since the images are very small.It seems obvious to me that the second P900 was defective. The issue might be wiring from the camera body to the LCD screen, or it might be in an internal sensing mechanism. The P900 has both a 3" LCD screen and an electronic viewfinder. Normally it senses if your eye is at the viewfinder and only activates the LCD if you're not using the viewfinder.Amazon has an inflexible 30-day return policy, which apparently includes defective products and which its independent sellers are free to enforce or not enforce.  30-days from my receipt of the camera had already passed when the problem arose and neither Amazon nor Pixiebytes will let me return the camera for refund or replacement.  Pixiebytes (which should change its name to  "Warning" Pixie Bites") wanted to know why I didn't contact them within 30 days. No matter that 30 days had just passed and I was in Italy when the LCD stopped working; no matter that I do not usually take purchase information and receipts with me when I travel.A few days ago I contacted Nikon and the agent I spoke with was both helpful and sympathetic. I learned from her that there is a "Gray Market," and if my camera was purchased from a seller on the Gray Market Nikon will not repair it.  (Grey Market products are manufactured for promotional purposes, not for sale.) If it's a full-fledged and fully backed Nikon, the cameras--both cameras--may be covered by Nikon's warranty. Unfortunately, the serial number of the second camera alone would not reveal if it is a Gray Market camera. (I couldn't locate the first Nikon while on the phone.) That can only be determined after I send it in. I intend to send both P900s.BUT LET THIS BE A WARNING TO ANYONE TRYING TO FIND A BARGAIN ON AMAZON:BEFORE YOU BUY ANYTHING LIKE A CAMERA FROM AN AMAZON SELLER, MAKE SURE THEY ARE A DEALER AUTHORIZED BY THE MANUFACTURER. AMAZON DOES NOT VERIFY THIS WHEN THEY ALLOW SELLERS TO LIST (IE, ADVERTISE) ON AMAZON.COM, AND SELLERS LIKE "PIXIE BITES" DO NOT STAND BEHIND THEIR PRODUCT IF THEY CAN POSSIBLY AVOID DOING SO.The two P900s cost me over $1200. I'd have saved money (and time, and frustration) had I bought just one camera at closer to list price from a genuine Nikon dealer.

We bought this XP90 for grandson. He loves to take pictures. Right out of the box issues - while charging one cannot take photos. It refuses to connect to my HP PC desktop, my wife's laptop, our Android phones (5.1.2), my daughter's iPhone 6, or my grandson's iPad. Lord knows what it is supposed to connect to but certainly nothing most folks have. And, yes, all devices are up-to-date as were all apps/programs/drivers downloaded and installed for the purpose. The odd thing is that it often "sees" the devices, it just refuses to connect to them. And, yes, they can connect to other wi-fi devices ... all our printers are  wi-fi and the home network is wi-fi and, in fact, my Android phone often gets control of the LG television in the doctor's office much to my amusement as I change channels on the unsuspecting patients waiting. ^_^ Maybe it's waiting for me to buy a Fuji computer ... trust me, the camera will still be waiting when something else freezes over.Actual photos. Well, they definitely leave something to be desired when compared with my Panasonic DMC-FH20 or Kodak P850. Auto focus is sketchy at best and at times as slow as the Kodak. One cannot take pictures of subjects that are backlit (which both Panasonic and Kodak can do). And indoors color selections are often way off the mark. And, forget night photos unless a bank of spot lights is illuminating the subject. Selecting automatic modes or tinkering with manual modes or any of the preset modes doesn't seem to help a whole lot.Earlier today I accidentally recorded a movie -- the movie button is separate and next to the ON/OFF button ^_^ -- and when I told it to erase the movie, it deleted all 500+ photos on the memory card without so much as a how-do-you-do or way to recover same.And just now, when I plugged it into a USB port to charge ... it don't wanna! < eyes rolling >. I disconnected and reconnected. No joy. Disconnected it, turn it off and reconnected it. Waited for an hour. Now it's charging. Apparently not only can you not take photos but you cannot charge with the camera on either. I guess you can USB or charge but not both. < more eye rolling >.If I could get my $240 back (camera, spare battery and 8GB Class SD card) I would do it in a heartbeat.

review_title: GREAT HIGH QUALITY CAMERA WITH MORE FEATURES THAN i COULD EVER IMAGINE and bundle a GREAT DEAL
review_body: I was a little scared to purchase a camera online as it's a major purchase,  but after looking locally found that the deal offered was just so much better than paying $795 with only one battery, no memory card and nothing else, so if I'd purchased locally at the big camera store I would probably have been closer to $950+ to get everything I got here.  So, I ordered this and couldn't be more pleased.Shipping was quite swift.  There was a mixup on the charger included, and Beach Camera swiftly made good on that.  I have to say I am impressed by all the stuff they included.  The Sony carrying case is very sturdy and could probably be dropped without damage to the camera.As to the camera, I upgraded from a Coolpix P80 which I used a lot for some years and liked for most of its features until I decided recently that there was something better out there.  However, this tiny but heavy little powerhouse, the RX100- III outshines the Coolpix by 500% in my opinion.  There is a learning curve to get to know all the features, but here are some I am already aware of.  First it has several little focus squares when you focus if you use the iP (intelligent focus) setting.  It goes to macro automatically in that setting and the results are pretty amazing.  It shoots well in dim light too.  It also shoots movies (very easy, again, to do, you just put it on iP and push the record button!) and you have a very clear movie which will record for about 29 minutes, the book says.  I haven't played the sound of my test movie on regular speakers but recorded Christopher on harpsichord.  The camera also has a stop action feature that takes 10 frames per second so you can go to a horserace, swim meet or the like and record in motion.  Haven't tried that but can hardly wait.I have ordered a book which explains all the features so think there's still a lot more to learn, but in the meantime, think this little camera is a great cross between the highest end portables and professional "big" cameras.  I am not a professional photographer but very much like taking pictures.I would recommend this camera, and also the company I bought it from.

review_title: Packs a lot into a very affordable price, but...
review_body: This camera is an amazing value in many ways.  It has an incredible zoom, 65x, and its image stabilization works beautifully to give you non-blurred images for hand held telephoto and low-light shots.  I've never experienced image stabilization like that before.  It has a very nice tilting LCD and of course an eyepiece viewfinder as well.  I appreciated its light weight and the ability to take macro photos at very close range.  I did not shoot video at all, so this review is based only on still shooting.There are a couple of bugs that do tend to get in the way of a fully enjoyable experience.  The principal one I kept running into was the camera unfocusing at moderate zoom levels.  It would focus and then unfocus.  The only way to get it to focus was to change the zoom level up or down, and by that time you may have lost your photo opportunity.  I also had the camera freeze a couple of times, and had to pop out the battery and push it back in to reset the camera.  This was in cold weather, so perhaps that was related, as my iPhone will sometimes do the same in the cold, when the battery cannot provide the necessary power.  The difference is that the iPhone shuts off, whereas this camera froze.The image sensor may be what is expected from a "bridge camera" such as this, but unfortunately I cannot honestly say "this camera takes really good pictures."  The sense I get from my iPhone 6 photos is that they are better in general.  A lot of that has to do I think with this camera's very limited "dynamic range", which essentially means the ability to handle scenes containing both bright and dark areas, which in my experience occurs frequently.  With this camera, the whites are often washed out.  The iPhone has an auto-HDR mode to handle this, and it is true that this camera also has HDR (which takes 3 shots and combines them), but you have to go through the menus every time you turn on the camera to enable HDR, and then taking photos becomes slower and uses the battery more quickly.  The camera has another mode called WDR, but I didn't find it helpful.  I think that mode is really intended for video scenes.  But even without HDR processing, a good camera ought to be able to produce decent images for high contrast scenes, and this camera really does not make the grade.

review_title: Decent image quality but lens scratches way too easy
review_body: I bought this for my wife to use on a 15 day float thru Grand Canyon.  Based on the reviews here and at DPreview, it sounded like a great option.I won’t fault the camera for image quality, since she was using it on Auto mode and most of the photos and videos turned out ok.  It struggled a bit with correct exposure due to high contrast of bright sky and darker canyon interiors which is to be expected.But this camera gets one star for the simple reason that it’s sold as a rugged camera designed for the water and the yet the lens is so horriblely  scratched after two weeks that I have to assume it’s not actually made from glass as advertised or some kind of cheap plastic.  She says she was using her shirt to wipe water of the lens once in awhile and that’s it. Unless the sun was directly behind her many of the photos have noticeable haze.You shouldn’t have to baby a camera that’s designed to function in dirty and wet environments.  I would not recommend this to someone who intends to use it in the way it’s advertisedUpdate: sent the camera back to Olympus to have the lens cover replaced and have been quoted $130.26 for the service.  Total rip off.  I’d return this if I could.  Will never buy an Olympus camera again.

I rate Beach Camera with five stars for promptness and for sending clean unopened packages.  There were also a few nice surprises that were included but not called out directly.Of course two spare batteries are highly welcomed and my package included a 12V charging cord and Euro AC adapter that were not called out in the descriptive copy.  As I use Mac computers, the Corel software package is not of use to me, but PC users will probably find it useful if they're not already committed to Lightshop, Photoshop or its variants.  Note that the SanDisc SD card included in this package is rated as speed class 3 so should get most users off to a proper running start.This review is obviously not a review of the camera per se but rather the package that Beach provides.  I judged it to be the best value of those on the Amazon page at this time which is why I selected it.  If you've decided on the RX100M6, this package is easy to recommend and I think the best value of those listed on Amazon at this time.As for the camera, I have to agree with the rest of the world's reviewers that this is a very expensive way to get a full time carry camera but if you're looking for some reach and want a small package, this is a good way to go.  Sony's descriptions and menus are just as annoying to learn as so many say it is but the hardware itself is excellent.

I'm an amateur photographer who is an admitted fan of Nikon Coolpix cameras. Prior to the arrival of my new A1000 on 25 March, I had previously acquired a Nikon Coolpix P530 (since gifted to a family member), B700, and P1000, in that order. The sequence reflects my desire for greater and greater optical zoom (42X > 60X > 125X). It also is an indication of my quest for additional features like capturing RAW data files. My primary subjects are landscapes and wildlife. For those who may not have a feel for the actual size of the A1000, the first two images I've included compare it to my B700 and P1000.When I saw the announcement for the new A1000, I was intrigued. Although it has less zoom (35X) than my current cameras, it has nearly all of their features and a couple that neither the B700 or P1000 possess. It has a touch LCD screen, for one. It also has the ability to select the number of shots (3 or 5) that the camera will take when Exposure Bracketing is enabled. This is a plus for using external software to process a series of High Dynamic Range (HDR) images.Since I've only had the A1000 for a few days, I haven't experimented with every aspect of its performance but I have taken enough pictures to begin to form some opinions and make some observations.1) The electronic viewfinder (EVF) is noticeably smaller than those on the B700 or P1000 but it gives a clear, crisp view of the images being framed. It also produces easily readable shooting parameter data and menus. The Diopter adjustment works well. The proximity sensor that automatically switches between the EVF and the LCD touch screen works as advertised but, until I got used to the placement of the sensor and EVF on the rear of the camera (left side vs centered), I found that I sometimes triggered the sensor with my left thumb during handling. NOTE: I've been using the viewfinder exclusively for shooting so I have no opinion on touch screen performance except to say that it's bright, clear and crisp when displaying menus and reviewing images.2) Zooming seems quick, smooth and accurate. Both zooming levers perform as they should as does the Snap Back button. NOTE: I've only used optical zoom because I've been capturing JPG and RAW data files in PSAM modes. When capturing RAW data files, digital zoom is disabled.3) So far, auto focusing seems quick with no hunting. The single exception I found was when I enabled Macro focusing for super close ups. I only tried a few shots, but on a couple of occasions, the camera struggled, hunting a bit before achieving a good focus.4) All the images I've shot so far were with the camera handheld using, with one exception, only PSAM modes - no tripod shots yet. The Vibration Reduction (VR) feature works great. I've only tried one Scene mode, Backlighting. For Backlighting, the camera takes a series of images and uses software in the camera to synthesize a single JPG image from the High Dynamic Range (HDR) images. It worked as it should.5) The protruding grip on the front of the camera is large enough to let one keep a firm grip but not so large as to compromise the camera's size. NOTE: I purchased a Case Logic DCB313 camera case into which the A1000 fits nicely.6) I see the A1000 mainly as a companion camera to the others I own but also as a primary device when zoom isn't that important and ease of carry comes to the fore.7) I compared images from the A1000 to those from the P1000 using similar subjects shot on different days. For each of the image pairs of the turtles and geese in the last six images, the first image is from the A1000 and the second from the P1000. The A1000 doesn't quite capture the very fine details that the P1000 does IMO. This doesn't surprise or disappoint me. I suspect that the relative size of their optics may account for this. That said, the images produced by the A1000 are great. NOTE: 99.999% of the images I've shot so far have been taken outdoors in sunlight. I've have no basis to comment yet about the A1000's low light performance.8) I haven't taken any video with A1000 so I have no basis to comment on that feature.Bottom Line: Based on just a few days of handling and shooting, I'm very pleased with the A1000.

review_title: A Nice Camera to Carry When You Want to Travel Light
review_body: I bought the Nikon A1000 as a camera to carry when I don’t want to carry a DSLR camera (and lenses), but want to have something to provide more zoom and better handling than a cell phone camera. I was waiting for Nikon to release the A1000 as it has the capability of shooting RAW images, and so far I am pleased with the camera.It’s important to note that point and shoot cameras with a long zoom like this, 24mm-840mm, usually have a small sensor, so you are not going to get the same results you get with a crop frame or full frame DSLR. That being said, you can get good results from this camera. All the photos posted here with this review were taken with the A1000 with very minor (or in some cases no) post processing.The A1000 has a number of modes – the standard P,S,A,M modes – as well as “Auto” and scene modes for more automatic operation. The vibration reduction is also very good on this camera, so you are able to zoom long distances and keep the ISO relatively low, or shoot indoor with low shutter speeds. The camera does have a pop-up flash if the subject is too dark, but no flash shoe. The camera also has a sensor so that when you bring it up to your eye to take a photo it activates the electronic viewfinder (EVF). The senor is sensitive so if you run your finger over it the image on the rear screen will be off and the electronic viewfinder will be activated. There is also a button to manually activate the EVF.Additionally, being a Nikon camera, the A1000 has great ergonomics and  feels more substantial than other point and shoot cameras I researched. It’s small enough to easily fit in a jacket pocket (or cargo shorts pocket) or purse, but not tiny so that I feel like it’s going break or I’m going to drop it. The rear screen folds out and down, for selfies, (or when you want to get down low for photos of kids and pets) and the camera connects pretty easily to Snapbridge, the Nikon app for transferring photos from your camera to your cell phone.The one negative for me is the battery charging door, which appears flimsy and looks like it will break after repeated usage. I suggest buying a separate charger and some spare batteries, so you can charge the batteries without using the camera. Battery life is on the low side (about 250 shots).Overall, I like this camera and can definitely recommend it, especially if you are looking for something with a lot of reach. There are 1 inch (sensor size) compact point and shoot cameras on the market, but they do not provide a zoom like the A1000. I would rate it 4.5 stars.

review_title: Good concept, but misses the mark for vlogging
review_body: After some real-life testing, I have concluded that this camera has some major technical issues that greatly affects its usability, particularly for vlogging. Although many of the boxes on the "perfect" vlogging design were checked, there were also some major issues such as the lack of continuous autofocus and some distortion on the 24mm lens (should not happen at this 35mm equivalent focal length). The lack of continuous autofocus is even more critical because of the shallow focusing plane offered by the large 1" sensor. When you are out vlogging, you are likely going to point your camera at other locations besides just yourself which will require re-focusing. In other words, if you switch from selfie mode to scenery mode in the same shot, the latter will be out of focus (DOA). The other issue of the lens distortion should not even occur at 24mm. The point of getting this camera was to avoid the GoPro-like fisheye distortion that may not be suitable for all situations. All software lens correction does is digitally fiddle with the image until it's less noticeable, but to the "trained" eye, it makes the image even worse because you will add distortion elsewhere. The manufacturers need to get more input from real vloggers and not designers who likely guess the requirements and inevitably miss the mark. I really wanted to like this camera, but these issues were just too significant to overcome as a vlogging camera.

I received this product to try as a Sony Ambassador and have been blown away. I spend a lot of my time outside and on the road, and am excited to continue working this camera into my process. As an outdoor and travel photographer, it is often important for me to be discreet when shooting. I have also always felt awkward vlogging with a big camera–– this one definitely makes that less of an issue. It's easy to add to your kit because of the small size, even on a grip. The flip screen is such a great option to have on a camera of this size. I also have to mention that the camera is waterproof and dust proof, for anyone with a more adventurous style of traveling/creating.  Overall this camera is a powerhouse and an excellent investment for anyone looking to add something new to their tool kit. I don't even know what could compete with it right now.

Some of Sony’s main competitors done even have an autofocus system like this in their flagship camera bodies. This camera seriously has all the best things we love about Sony in a really small profile. It’s a great tool to have in your bag I take it with me wherever I go.

That's where it ends.For an action-cam, it's too limited. Abysmal battery life on its own, and no way to extend the battery life while keeping it waterproof. As a remote/perspective cam it's crippled by the fact that you CAN NOT CONTROL 4K RECORDING OF THIS CAMERA FROM YOUR SMARTPHONE! The "Ctrl f/Smartphone" function is disabled when set to 4K recording, and the only way to enable it is it drop it to FHD recording. But even if you get set it up for 4K recording, the camera will overheat and shut down after 20-25 minutes... just short of the battery giving out.The limited footage it produces is good. However, it's too limited for me. The waterproof bit is useless if I can't take it snorkeling for a couple of hours without risking salt-water ingress while swapping batteries. I can't set it up as a remote camera, because there's no way to start/stop recording without physically touching the camera - and I can't leave it recording, even with USB power, for extended periods of time, because it will overheat and shut down.But then, if I want a good camera for short 4K clips, I can just use my phone. review_title: Good overall camera with some minor drawbacks and some great special features
review_body: Overall a good camera. I was initially unhappy with it over the lack of a lens cover which costs $50 and isn't available. We finally bought another adapter and 2 lens covers for about $17 - Filter Adapter JJC Conversion Lens Ring Adapter Ring Mount 40.5mm Filter and 2 Pack JJC 40.5mm Front Lens Cap Cover with Deluxe Cap Keeper - they're not as good due to having to deal with a hanging lens cap, but work alright. Sooner or later the lens will be scratched without a cover.The default settings make very low quality photos, but once you figure out how to set them to the highest quality, the photos are quite good. The manual that you have to download is not very clear about the different options.It would be better if it came with an extra battery and external charger, as well as a case.I'm very pleased with the Microscopic functions. The automatically stacking microscopic functions appear to me to be better than a dedicated macro lens on a DSL. Sometimes you get extra antennae or legs, but I'm amazed at how easy it makes taking good photos of very small objects, even tiny insects that aren't still.It seems to get the focus and exposure right on almost every photo, and is very fast. It is very worthwhile reading the manual, because there are many "hi-tech" functions that are very useful and can save you lots of time.The lack of a larger zoom is frustrating, but not as bad as I expected. Battery life is excellent, and the GPS works well, even if a little slow to hook up at first.  I would have given it 4-5 stars if the lens cover was not such an issue, and for $450 there should be a case and extra battery with a charger.

review_title: Likely the best rugged compact camera on the market
review_body: Strengths:Takes good high quality images for a 12 MP compact.  Pictures are bright and performance in lowlight is very good.  Macro is exceptional and underwater photos are very strong (easily the best among other compact UW cameras).  Dynamic range is very good and shadows are often properly exposed (unlike most other UW cameras that consistently underexpose shadows).  Despite this camera having only 12 MP, it frequently provides cleaner and more detailed images than its 16 and 20 MP competitors.  The custom settings are awesome...everything from the ability to shoot raw, the ability to set and stick 1 second shake reduction timers, to the custom saturation/gradation/contrast/sharpness/nr settings, and much more.  White balance tends to be good especially in indoor/macro/uw settings.  Reds perform well with this camera.  Scenes modes (like beach mode) tend to work well.Weaknesses:Video stabilization is a bit below average but decent and low light videos are brighter than the competition.  This cameras is a low floor, high ceiling camera...you will need to learn how to use it to gets best benefits.  At times the produced jpgs are too saturated or undersaturated.  I find a good work around is program mode > i-enhance (low) with NR (low) which works well in most cases.  If you edit raw, you don't have to worry about that.  Blues and greens are a bit weak in distant landscape shots.Minor Quips:A wrist strap is included...good for divers, but for paddlers, skiers, and hikers a neck strap would have been preferred.  4x zoom is a bit below average compared to other UW compacts...but zoom quality isn't bad and you can always purchased a telephoto addon to double the range.  There is no 4k 60p (just 4k 30p or 1080 60p), but few competitors for this class of camera off this.  The battery door and tripod mount are located next to each other...so if you need to switch batteries, you'll also need to remove your quick release mount which is a bit annoying.TG-5 vs TG-6:On paper, the TG-6 hasn't improved much, but there are subtle but important improvements.  New internal filters have been added to reduce chromatic aberration and the purple orb issues.  White balance appears slightly improved in the TG-6 and images are much less like to be overexposed (an issues with the TG-5).  The LCD on the TG-6 is much approved which is very handy when doing things like exposure compensation.  Minimum shutter speed controls, super-macro video, and the ability to use microscope focus in aperture priority are significant changes as well.Purple Orb:All TG cameras (and many non-Olympus cameras) occasionally show a small purple orb in the middle of the image.  This is likely light reflecting off of the sensor onto an internal lens element.  No reviewer brings it up, but it does exist.  Honestly I wouldn't panic if you see this.  I've shot 1000's of TG-6 outdoor images and maybe only 1-2 show this.  It is more apt to show indoors and in macro situations.  But...it only appears in select contexts.  Usually if you have max zoom, have a dark subject at the very center, are using a high iso, and there is a strong off-axis light source (or flat surface nearby like a wall that reflects a lot of light).  The new LCD screen makes it easy to see the orb and react accordingly...use the flash (the flash cures this in my experience), zoom out, or recompose the camera so the very center isn't on something very dark.  While many TG-5 users complained of this, I believe this has been significantly reduced in the TG-6, but it will occasionally happen...it's normal!Accessories:The FD-1 is highly recommended for macro and acts as a lens hood to protect the lens.  Screen protectors are recommended too (a two pack for $7 is available if you search Amazon "screen protectors olympus tough".  An external charger and backup batteries are recommend.  Li92 are better quality...but Li90 are a significantly better value.  Search Amazon "bm Batteries and Charger for Olympus Tough" for a nice charger/battery pack combo.

review_title: I picked this up to help me with my vlogs
review_body: I picked this up to help me with my vlogs. Previously I had been using a webcam, but wanted to upgrade to something better but without costing a fortune.I was very pleased with the picture quality and coupled with the HD option it really did improve my videos from my previous cameras. It also comes with a night mode that improves low light level recording. Whilst this isn't something I would use, it appeared to work very well during my tests.

Bought this camera to replace an old snapshot camera. Really like this one! Great photos. Takes pictures quickly so you don't lose that special shot. Good quality too. Telephoto works great and is intuitive. Pull the lever toward you to get closer to your subject, push to decrease. Takes video too although I haven't used it for that yet. Lightweight, slim and compact. Great all around snapshot camera!

I LOVE IT ! Needed some practice at first,because what you're looking in the hole is not what the camera take as picture.. not quite the same angle... but the pictures are clear and nice.You need to use the right "mode" everytime or the picture will be bad.Cute and fit in a wallet.

review_title: Records decent video for my brother's party
review_body: My sister's 16th birthday was coming up so i really needed a bargain camera to record and have a professional pan of her best moments to make a decent video after her birthday, so i looked for chap but bargain one; after reading the review i decided that this was the one for me, it worked really well and couldn't be better for the current price i played.Video and picture quality is very good,The price as you'd notice is a great bargain for me and i think other people should take advantage of this price too.For first use of this camera i really think it was fairly straight forward and did not have any complicated set up for me.really was a great benefit to see. This would work for small and family based events.

With your mobile phone being able to take perfectly serviceable photos (and better) these days you might question the need for a product like this. Well maybe you don't want your child throwing your I-Phone about and breaking it.At 5MP it's not breaking the technological barriers but as a fun kid's toy it's great. It's sturdily built and will withstand the usual bumps and bruises of everyday life. The pictures it's takes are fine in ""normal""condition and a little less fine in other conditions but that's to be expected with something like this.and you need buy a SD Card yourself and generally it's just great fun for kids who might have an interest in taking photos but can't yet be trusted with anything more flimsy!

review_body: Auto focus is really bad. It really takes 3-5 secs to focus on my face. Canon also removes the face id features for mark 3 and when shooting in 4k it overheats after 10 mins of recording.

I have to give it 2 stars for ambition and design. It feels better than my Mark II and it was made with good intentions. After overheating in 4k, absolutely terrible autofocus in video, and no 24fps I returned it to Adorama. Canon came so close with this one but it just isn't a good option. I'd recommend the Mark II over the III any day.

These are some test shots just taken today. I still have much to learn, but I'll be testing this tonight to see how it performs in low light. What I did notice is the auto focus is iffy when trying to take macro photos. It often will focus on the background instead of the main subject. As you can see in the last photo of the daisy I attached, it's not as crisp as it could be. Will update my review later with more findings!
The mic port and un-cropped 4K capabilities packed into such a small camera is a huge win for Canon. Love it and will use this for years to come in my studio and vlogs.

review_body: There is a great review on the tube by user "DYOS-KIS" for this camera.

review_title: Worse autofocus than the Mark ii, Firmware update unheard of...
review_body: I was extremely ecstatic to get my hands on this camera. Long story short, I ended up returning the camera. Autofocus is slower than on the Mark ii. Why pay more for something that’s less functional? I can’t just hope that a firmware update is coming soon. Going back to the trusty Mark ii, and saved some $$ while doing so. I’m confused.... Autofocus is crucial when recording video, and it has somehow gotten worse...

review_title: Autofocus for video is very slow and often inaccurate
review_body: I wanted to step up from just recording videos on my smartphone to a "proper" camera. The autofocus is really quite bad. My smartphone has significantly better autofocus. Most of the videos I've shot so far have all been out of focus. When taking photos it's a bit faster though, feels nice. What perplexed me was that, while recording a video, the camera would track my face and other faces quite well and reliably but fail to focus on it at all. If you stay still after tapping onto your face, it takes a good 5 seconds on average to focus. I wanted to like this camera but find myself picking up my smartphone to record videos more reliably.

review_title: Serious Focus issues in video mode
review_body: Canon has a bit of a dud on their hands with the G7x Mark III. At least for video mode, the focus is really bad. It's very slow to focus and usually misses focus altogether. It was so bad, that while I really wanted to love this camera, I ended up having to return it. Unless Canon fixes the issue with a firmware update, I would say avoid this camera unless you do not plan on using it for video at all (since it seems quite good for stills).It's too bad because the external mic jack on this + the ability to shoot in 4K were huge selling points for me.

Avoid this camera! Video autofocus, when it works, is horrible! Even if the focus box is around the subject it’s probably not in focus. 4k is a waste of time - it over heats in about 2-3mins. The 1080/30 looks ok, but (in my opinion) 25 fps in PAL mode looks much better (...completely baffled as to why Canon would drop 24 fps from their recent cameras...). It’s like Canon released a beta version of this camera instead of the finished product. I’ve had the Mark ii for several years, it’s still a great camera, and performs significantly better than the Mark iii.
